Operating, maintenance, training, and safety procedures will be formalized with improved written documentation.

4. Five-Year Accident History

Although the facility is not a new facility, it will be operated by a new operator. Under the previous operator, there has been no releases of anhydrous ammonia in the last 5 years that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

5. Emergency Response Program

Taylor 2 facility is a Non-Responding facility. Facility only responds to situations that are within their capabilities. These may include, emergency shutdown, equipment isolation and pumping down the system. No emergency response actions or site clean-up that are beyond the capabilities of the refrigeration personnel will be performed. In case of an emergency, incident will be reported immediately to the RMP Program Coordinator. The RMP Program Coordinator is responsible for assisting county emergency responders upon arrival on site. This may include contacting emergency response agencies, schools, daycare centers, and acute care facilities that may be affected by the release. The RMP Program Coordinator will also be responsible for evacuation of employees if necessary and for coordination with community emergency responders if off-site evacuations are required.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Recommended corrective actions to mitigate the potential for an accidental ammonia release are proposed on the tables located in RMP Binder Chapter 0.0. The table items result from recommendations made during the Process Hazard Analysis, a Code Compliance Review, Seismic Review, and a Safety Inspection performed by a qualified person. Some recommendation items in the recommendation table originate from multiple codes but are listed only once. Specific facility areas and systems categorize recommendations

ute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) Ammonia Refrigeration Safety Inspection Checklists, located in Appendix 12 of the RMP Binder, describe equipment details. 

The refrigeration systems at this facility are single-stage vapor compression cycles. In general, the process chemistry for the refrigeration systems is provided in Chapter 8 of the RMP Binder. 

Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is a gas in its natural state and is extremely irritating to mucous membranes and lung tissue. The gas is pungent and may be suffocating as shortness of breath and labored breathing can develop if inhaled. Prolonged inhalation of high concentrations may cause bronchitis and/ or pneumonia, with some residual reduction in pulmonary functions. Repeated or prolonged contact of high concentrations of ammonia to the skin can cause frostbite, redness, pain and serious skin burn. See Chapter 8 Appendix 8.4 for Safety Data Sheets (SDS) for anhydrous ammonia.

3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Taylor 2 facility maintains a release prevention program to prevent or mitigate releases. The program includes regular inspections, monitoring equipment and logging conditions, scheduled maintenance, and operator training. There is a program to analyze releases for ways to prevent a similar future release, see Appendix 16 - Incident Investigation of the RMP Binder.

The ammonia refrigeration system has specific safety procedures to prevent a release. Operators, contractors and mechanics are trained for safe operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system. They are also trained in emergency reporting and monitoring and assisting local emergency responders in the event of an ammonia release. There are emergency shut-off switches outside the machinery room for shutting down the Main System. Ammonia detectors are installed in all of the refrigerated rooms and the engine room. The alarm company (First Alarm) notifies the personnel in the list, if any detector exceeds its set point. All

alling film heat exchangers. All the refrigeration equipment of this system is located outdoors, next to R-0816 refrigeration equipment. Refrigeration trailer is comprised of high-side equipment only, which includes high-pressure receiver, one screw compressor w/ oil separator, evaporative condenser, control, valves, and piping. The ammonia charge of the R-21 system is approximately 2,700 lbs.

Vacuum cooling system serves the vacuum tube coil. This system is used for vacuum cooling operations. All the refrigeration equipment of this system is located outdoors. Refrigeration trailer (R-1202) is comprised of high-and low-side equipment, which includes high-pressure receiver, two reciprocating compressors w/ oil separators, low-pressure receiver w/ ammonia pumps and oil pot, evaporative condenser, control, valves, and piping. The ammonia charge of this system is approximately 2,575 lbs.

The total ammonia charge in all the refrigeration systems at the facility is approximately 23,215 lb.

All compressors have safety switches that would shut down the compressors upon detection of unsafe operating conditions. Low-pressure receivers have high level float switches that shut down the compressors when it senses high liquid level in the vessel. 

Ammonia detection system sends alarms to a third-party alarm company (First Alarm Company), which in return calls the listed facility personnel in case of ammonia detection in the cold rooms or engine room. All pressure vessels and compressors are protected against high-pressure situations by safety relief valves. There are assigned responders (refrigeration contractors) experienced with ammonia refrigeration that would respond to and determine specific actions for any incident. 

Refrigeration system drawings are located in the Chapter 8 Appendix 8.1 (Refrigeration System Drawings) of the RMP Binder. A list of refrigeration equipment used at this facility can be found in Appendix 12 of the RMP Binder. International Instit

aporators in the cold rooms and four of the falling film heat exchangers that are used for water chilling. Main System is comprised of evaporative condensers, pressure vessels, screw and reciprocating compressors, cold room evaporators (fan coils), falling film water chillers (four of them only), ammonia detection, control systems and diffusion tank. The facility has four cold rooms housing air-cooled evaporators (fan coils): the Cold Room 1, Cold Room 2, Cold Room 3, and Cold Room 4 (currently not in use). Main System will be operated seasonally from April to November. At the end of the season, portable equipment will ship to Yuma, AZ facility for winter operations, from November to April. The ammonia charge of the Main System including the portable equipment (four falling film heat exchanger) is approximately 14,340 lbs.

Facility has a refrigeration machinery room that is part of the Main System. Machinery room houses the screw and reciprocating compressors, high-pressure receiver, low pressure receivers w/ ammonia pumps and oil pots. Evaporators are located in the cold rooms. Condensers are located on the machinery room roof. Falling film heat exchangers are located outside the machinery room.

R-0816 refrigeration trailer serves the remaining falling film heat exchangers (8 of them). This system is used for water chilling operations. All the refrigeration equipment of this system is located outdoors, and chilled water is pumped to the processing room. Refrigeration trailer is comprised of high-and low-side equipment, which includes high-pressure receiver, three reciprocating compressors w/ oil separators, low-pressure receiver w/ ammonia pumps and oil pot, evaporative condenser, control, valves, and piping. The ammonia charge of the R-0816 system is approximately 3,600 lbs.

R-21 refrigeration trailer serves the make-up water chiller skid (plate frame heat exchanger, surge drum, and oil pot). This system is used for chilling of the make-up water for the f

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Taylor 2 facility conducts inspection procedures to review refrigeration equipment prior to startup and during operations. These procedures identify potential sources of release and equipment corrections required to prevent these releases. On-site personnel and certified refrigeration contractors review the equipment as required. On-site personnel provide initial emergency response.

On-site personnel will make a preliminary assessment in the event of a release and will provide first response. First response may include emergency equipment shutdown, system isolation, or controlled operation such as pump down to prevent or reduce an off-site release. No emergency operations will be performed that are beyond the capabilities of the operators or other on-site personnel. Local fire and police departments with mutual aid response will provide emergency response for a major release event. Refrigeration contractors would also be on-call to provide emergency response. Emergency response training will be conducted yearly for current employees and as required for new employees. Records will be kept of all training performed at the site for a minimum of five (5) years.

2. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The Taylor 2 facility uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant in their operations. See Chapter 8 Appendix 8.1 of the RMP binder for the drawings showing the facility location map and site plan.
The ammonia system is used for cold storage and water chilling. There are four separate refrigeration systems at the facility: Main Refrigeration System (Main System), R-0816 full refrigeration trailer (high-side and low-side), R-21 high-side refrigeration trailer connected to a make-up water chiller skid with surge drum, and a vacuum cooling system that is comprised of a half-car vacuum tube and a refrigeration tailer (T-1202 & R-1202).
